From Wiktionary, the free dictionary
See also: poudré

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

Inherited from Old French poudre, poldre, from Late Latin pulvera, neuter plural based on Latin pulvis m, from Proto-Indo-European *pel- (“dust; flour”).

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /pudʁ/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (France (Lyon)):(file)

Noun

[edit]

poudre f (plural poudres)

  1. (obsolete) dust
    Synonym: poussière
  2. powder

Derived terms

[edit]
  • comme une traînée de poudre
  • faire de la poudre
  • faire parler la poudre
  • lait en poudre
  • mettre le feu aux poudres
  • ne pas avoir inventé la poudre
  • poudre à canon
  • poudre à laver
  • poudre à lessiver
  • poudre aux yeux
  • poudre de perlimpinpin
  • poudre d'escampette
  • poudre Shimosa
  • poudrer
  • poudrerie
  • poudrette
  • poudreuse
  • poudreux
  • prendre la poudre d'escampette
  • sucre en poudre

Related terms

[edit]
  • poussière
  • pulvériser

Descendants

[edit]
  • → Azerbaijani: pudra
  • → Belarusian: пудра (pudra)
  • → Faroese: putur
  • → German: Puder
  • → Greek: πούδρα (poúdra)
  • → Hungarian: púder
  • → Macedonian: пудра (pudra)
  • → Norwegian: pudder
  • → Ottoman Turkish: پودره (pudra)
    • Turkish: pudra
  • → Persian: پودر (pudr)
  • → Polish: puder
  • → Romanian: pudră
  • → Russian: пудра (pudra)
  • → Serbo-Croatian: puder / пудер
  • → Slovene: puder
  • → Spanish: puder
  • → Swedish: puder
    • → Finnish: puuteri
  • → Ukrainian: пудра (pudra)
  • → Yiddish: פּודער (puder)

Further reading

[edit]
  • “poudre”, in Trésor de la langue française informatisé [Digitized Treasury of the French Language], 2012.

Middle English

[edit]

Etymology 1

[edit]

From Old French poudre, ultimately from Latin pulvis.

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • powder, pouder, powdre, pouldre, powdir, powdyr, pudre, poudur, poweder, pouþer, powþer, powther, powdur

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /ˈpuːdər/, /ˈpuːðər/, /ˈpuːdrə/

Noun

[edit]

poudre (plural poudres)

  1. powder (a collection of particles):
    1. Dust; powder as a waste products or generated from the remains of something.
    2. Ashes; the matter produced by combustion.
    3. Earth, dirt; the particles that compose soil.
    4. Various powders as used in medicine or alchemy.
    5. Powders used for culinary purposes; spices.
    6. (rare) Gunpowder; black powder.
  2. The results of the decomposition of one's corpse.
  3. (rare) A speckling; an stippled pattern.
Derived terms
[edit]
  • gunnepoudre
  • poudren
Descendants
[edit]
  • English: powder (see there for further descendants)
  • Scots: pouder, pouther
  • → Welsh: powdr, powdwr, pwdr
References
[edit]
  • “pǒudre, n.(1).”, in MED Online, Ann Arbor, Mich.: University of Michigan, 2007, retrieved 22 July 2018.

Etymology 2

[edit]

Verb

[edit]

poudre

  1. alternative form of poudren

Old French

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • puldre, pudre, poldre, podre
  • polre (Picardy, Lorraine)
  • pourre (Champagne)
  • poure, pourre

Etymology

[edit]

From Late Latin pulvera, neuter plural based on Latin pulvis m, from Proto-Indo-European *pel- (“dust; flour”). Compare Old Occitan poldra, polvera.

Noun

[edit]

poudre oblique singular, f (oblique plural poudres, nominative singular poudre, nominative plural poudres)

  1. powder
  2. dust

Related terms

[edit]
  • pous

Descendants

[edit]
Descendants
  • French: poudre (see there for further descendants)
  • Norman: poudre
  • Walloon: poure, poude
  • → Middle Dutch: poeder
    • Dutch: poeder, poeier (colloquial)
      • Afrikaans: poeier
      • → Indonesian: pudêr, puyer, puyêr
      • → Papiamentu: puiru, poeier
      • → Sranan Tongo: puiri
        • → Aukan: puili
        • → Caribbean Hindustani: puiri
    • Limburgish: pójjer
  • → Middle English: poudre, powder, pouder, powdre, pouldre, powdir, powdyr, pudre, poudur, poweder, pouþer, powþer, powther, powdur
    • English: powder (see there for further descendants)
    • Scots: pouder, pouther
    • → Welsh: powdr, powdwr, pwdr
  • → Middle Irish: púdar
    • Irish: púdar
    • Manx: poodyr
    • Scottish Gaelic: fùdar, pùdar

References

[edit]
  • Walther von Wartburg (1928–2002), “pŭlvis”, in Französisches Etymologisches Wörterbuch, volume 9: Placabilis–Pyxis, page 561
